posts.cooked: Im a member on a rookie team and for this game we decided to build an elevator, but we have no idea how to code any of it. We tried to find code that would work, but we could only find bits of code that we didn’t know how to use. We figured out how to make the elevator go up and down but we want it to go to a specific spot and stay there with the push of a button. We are using an xbox controller and our elevator is ran off 1 motor. Any help would be greatly appreciated.

posts.name: Noah Simon
posts.cooked:
Hi there!

Our team is also programming an elevator this year, and I believe the trick to have the type of movement your looking for is a gravity feedforward model combined with a PID controller.

Essentially, you want to find the voltage that, when applied to your elevator, will perfectly counteract gravity. Then you should constantly apply that voltage. This is commonly referred to as “kG”. From there, a standard PID controller will be able to bring you to any given setpoint ( PID output + gravity feedforward)

If you are struggling to increase movement efficiency or accuracy, you can go a step further and add in a friction feedforward model (“kS”), and if you want to go even further you can utilize a motion profile with tuned velocity and acceleration control (kV).

The gravity and friction setup can be done with an ElevatorFeedforward object, part of wpilib, while the motion profile can be done with a ProfiledPIDController. The wpilib docs will do far better at explaining than I will, but feel free to ask me any questions! I’d be happy to share my team’s setup and tuning methods

posts.name: Owen Busler
posts.cooked: This is a great explanation! If you share what motor/motor controller you are using we can give you more concrete examples.
We are using neos with spark maxes
I am trying to use the rev example for smart motion using PIDs but it seems to be outdated and doesn’t seem to work. Are there any fixes or better examples?

posts.cooked: Thanks I will try this when I get in shop tommorow.
Sounds good! Glad I could help! Make sure you understand how it works before just deploying to robot though

If you want to get a head start on practicing tuning, the wplib docs has a model you can play around with: Tuning a Vertical Elevator with Motion Profiling — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

Also, one thing to note with tuning is it doesn’t need to be perfect; getting something working is impressive enough. You can also cheat a bit with tuning by using SysID to help find the constants, Introduction to System Identification — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation , but if its more complicated than it will save you time, don’t bother.
